title: 111_hr5913
content:
The "Text a Tip Act of 2010" establishes a pilot program for texting crime tips. The Attorney General may grant funds to law enforcement agencies for an anonymous tip program using cell phone text messaging. The funds can be used for operating costs, promotion, and the federal share should not exceed 75 percent of the program cost. Grant amounts should supplement non-Federal funds, not replace them. The program requirements for the anonymous tip program using cell phone text messaging include grant funds for operating costs and promotion, with the federal share not exceeding 75 percent of the program cost. Grant amounts should supplement non-Federal funds, not replace them. A texting tip program of a State or local law enforcement agency eligible for a grant under this Act must comply with requirements such as administering the program, stripping incoming text messages of identifying information, ensuring texts are untraceable, not replacing existing hotlines, training personnel to respond to tips, making the program compatible with mobile phone providers, and including an unidentifiable code for follow-up information. The texting program for law enforcement agencies must allow tipsters to abort tips, not charge additional fees, and promote participation, especially among youth. To apply for a grant under this Act, a State or local law enforcement agency must submit an application to the Attorney General with required information. Each application must certify that the program meets the Act's requirements. Recipients of grants must submit yearly reports on the effectiveness of activities funded by the grant, and the Attorney General must provide a yearly report to the Senate and House Judiciary Committees on the activities' effectiveness. SEC. 6. DEFINITIONS.

The term "texting tip program" allows citizens to anonymously text tips to aid law enforcement in preventing and solving crimes. "Texting" refers to sending written messages from a mobile phone.

SEC. 7. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS.

$5,000,000 is authorized for each fiscal year from 2011 to 2016 for the Attorney General to carry out this Act.
